options.label: B

options.text: To increase the yield of the tree

title: How Americans got stuck with endless drug commercials

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique aspect of prescription drug commercials in the US compared to most other countries?

options.label: A
options.text: They are only shown only on television.

options.label: C
options.text: They are allowed on television, but not in print.

options.label: D
options.text: They are allowed on television, but with restrictions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason that pharmaceutical companies initially focused their marketing solely on doctors rather than the general public?

options.label: A
options.text: They wanted to keep costs down.

options.label: B
options.text: They wanted to avoid hurting their relationships with doctors.

options.label: C
options.text: They were not allowed to market directly to the public.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not have the resources to market to the public.

multiple-choice.question: What was the FDA's initial interpretation of its regulations regarding prescription drug commercials?

options.label: A
options.text: They required ads to include all of the information about the drug's risks and side effects.

options.label: B
options.text: They required ads to include only the major side effects.

options.label: C
options.text: They required ads to mention the disease or condition that the drug was supposed to treat.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not have any regulations regarding prescription drug commercials.

multiple-choice.question: What loophole allowed prescription drug commercials to appear on television despite the FDA's initial regulations?

options.label: A
options.text: The ads didn't have to mention the drug's risks if they also didn't mention the disease or condition that the drug was supposed to treat.

options.label: B
options.text: The ads didn't have to mention the disease or condition that the drug was supposed to treat.

options.label: C
options.text: The ads didn't have to mention the drug's risks.

options.label: D
options.text: The ads didn't have to include any information about the drug's risks and side effects.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to spending on prescription drug commercials after the FDA clarified its regulations in 1997?
What study found that doctors were more likely to prescribe antidepressants to patients who mentioned seeing a commercial for Paxil?

options.label: A
options.text: A study by the actors reported symptoms of depression.

options.label: B
options.text: A study the actors said they were feeling down after becoming unemployed.

options.label: C
options.text: A study the actors mentioned seeing an advertisement for Paxil on TV.

options.label: D
options.text: A study the actors didn't bring up medication at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument against prescription drug commercials?

options.label: A
options.text: They give the industry an incentive to make healthy people feel unhealthy.

options.label: B
options.text: They contribute to unrealistic expectations about what pharmaceuticals can do.

options.label: C
options.text: They are misleading and do not provide accurate information.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the painkiller Vioxx after a massive ad campaign led millions of people to switch to it?

options.label: A
options.text: It was approved by the FDA.

options.label: B
options.text: It was recalled from the market due to health concerns.

options.label: D
options.text: It was sold to a different company.

multiple-choice.question: What is the strongest argument in favor of prescription drug commercials?

options.label: A
options.text: They are effective in educating patients about their health.

options.label: B
options.text: They are good for public health.

options.label: C
options.text: They are protected by the First Amendment.

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote a dissenting opinion in the Supreme Court case that ruled in favor of prescription drug advertising?

title: How to talk to people you disagree with

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the room the speaker is in, despite its appearance of holding 600 people?
According to the speaker, what is the equation in her family regarding intelligence and spirituality?

options.label: A
options.text: If you are intelligent, you are therefore spiritual.

options.label: B
options.text: If you are intelligent, you are therefore not spiritual.

options.label: C
options.text: If you are spiritual, you are therefore intelligent.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the concept in African culture that means "I need you in order to be me, and you need me in order to be you"?
According to the speaker, what is the worst era in human history that started with negative otherizing?
What is the name of the speaker's initiative to counteract the tendency to otherize?
What is the goal of the speaker's initiative "Take the Other to Lunch"?

options.label: A
options.text: To persuade others to one's point of view

options.label: B
options.text: To get to know one person from a group one may have negatively stereotyped

options.label: C
options.text: To interrupt others and defend one's own point of view

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore others and focus on oneself

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the ground rules for taking someone to lunch as part of her initiative?

options.label: A
options.text: Don't persuade, defend, or interrupt; be curious, be conversational, be real; and listen

options.label: B
options.text: Persuade, defend, and interrupt; be judgmental, be critical, be argumentative

options.label: C
options.text: Don't talk about politics or religion; only discuss sports and entertainment

options.label: D
options.text: Only talk about one's own experiences and don't ask questions

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the purpose of taking someone to lunch as part of her initiative?

options.label: A
options.text: To change the other person's point of view

options.label: B
options.text: To understand and acknowledge the other person's perspective

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the other person and focus on oneself

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid conflict and pretend that differences don't exist

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the "ubuntu place"?

options.label: A
options.text: A place where people agree on everything

options.label: B
options.text: A place where people understand and acknowledge each other's perspectives

options.label: C
options.text: A place where people pretend to be friends but secretly dislike each other

options.label: D
options.text: A place where people only talk about themselves

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the quote from Rumi that describes the "ubuntu place"?

options.label: B
options.text: "Out beyond ideas of wrong-doing and right-doing, there is a field. I'll meet you there."

title: Aphasia: The disorder that makes you lose your words - Susan Wortman-Jutt

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the language disorder that can impair all aspects of communication?
Which of the following types of aphasia is characterized by normal vocal inflection but use of words that lack meaning?
Which area of the brain is responsible for naming objects and coordinating the muscles involved in speech?
According to the text, approximately how many people in the U.S. have aphasia?
What is the rare form of aphasia that is not caused by stroke or brain injury but is actually a form of dementia in which language loss is the first symptom?
Which of the following is a characteristic of non-fluent aphasia?

options.label: C
options.text: Good comprehension but long hesitations between words

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the brain's ability to repair itself and permit areas surrounding a brain lesion to take over some functions during the recovery process?
What is the estimated number of new cases of aphasia per year in the U.S.?
According to the text, what percentage of stroke survivors suffer from aphasia?
What is the goal in treating primary progressive aphasia (PPA)?

options.label: B
options.text: To maintain language function for as long as possible

options.label: D
options.text: To slow down the progression of the disease

title: What's the ultimate campfire fuel?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between wood and charcoal as fuel sources?

options.label: A
options.text: Wood releases more heat energy and less smoke when it burns.

options.label: B
options.text: Charcoal is a product of wood pyrolysis.

options.label: C
options.text: Charcoal releases more heat energy and less smoke when it burns.

options.label: D
options.text: Wood is made up of long chains of glucose molecules called cellulose.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when organic molecules break apart in a fire?
What is the primary byproduct of pyrolysis in a fire?
Why does a fire produce more heat when there is plenty of oxygen available?

options.label: A
options.text: Because oxygen is a fuel source.

options.label: B
options.text: Because oxygen helps to break down organic molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: Because oxygen reacts with volatile gases to create more heat.

options.label: D
options.text: Because oxygen is not a factor in the combustion process.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the remaining material from burning wood?
How is industrial charcoal mass produced?

options.label: A
options.text: By heating up wood or wood products with plenty of oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: By heating up wood or wood products without much oxygen.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of wood and charcoal as fuel.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a different type of fuel altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary economic issue associated with using charcoal as a fuel source?

options.label: A
options.text: Deforestation in parts of Africa and South America.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern with using wood as a fuel source?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces more heat energy and less smoke than charcoal.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a product of wood pyrolysis.

options.label: C
options.text: It can cause deforestation in parts of Africa and South America.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a combustible fuel source.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of initiating policies and research efforts to conserve charcoal resources?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the production of charcoal.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the environmental impact of charcoal production.

options.label: C
options.text: To conserve charcoal resources and use them more efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate the use of charcoal as a fuel source.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using charcoal as a fuel source?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces more heat energy and less smoke than wood.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a product of wood pyrolysis.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a renewable energy source.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a non-toxic and environmentally friendly.

title: What is a vector? - David Huynh

multiple-choice.question: What is a scalar?

options.label: A
options.text: A quantity with both magnitude and direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A quantity with magnitude but no direction.

options.label: C
options.text: A quantity with direction but no magnitude.

options.label: D
options.text: A quantity with neither magnitude nor direction.

multiple-choice.question: What makes vectors special and useful in various fields?

options.label: B
options.text: They remain invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used in physics.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in video games.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the coordinate basis in describing vectors?

options.label: A
options.text: To change the direction of the vector.

options.label: B
options.text: To give the vector context and meaning.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the vector more complex.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the vector less useful.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the two arrays used to describe the same vector?

options.label: A
options.text: One array has a different basis, while the other array has the same basis.

options.label: B
options.text: One array is more complex than the other array.

options.label: C
options.text: One array is used for a different purpose than the other array.

options.label: D
options.text: One array is used in a different field than the other array.

multiple-choice.question: What is the essence of a vector?

options.label: C
options.text: The vector itself, regardless of the language used to describe it.

options.label: D
options.text: The coordinate basis used to describe the vector.

multiple-choice.question: What property do scalars share with vectors?

options.label: B
options.text: They remain invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used in physics.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in video games.

multiple-choice.question: What is a tensor?

options.label: A
options.text: A quantity with magnitude but no direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A quantity with direction but no magnitude.

options.label: C
options.text: A quantity with both magnitude and direction that remains invariant to the coordinate system.

options.label: D
options.text: A quantity with neither magnitude nor direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a second-order tensor?

options.label: C
options.text: Stress, which is a combination of force and orientation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of tensors in various fields?

options.label: A
options.text: To make complex ideas and interactions more difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: To make complex ideas and interactions more simple and elegant.

options.label: C
options.text: To only be used in physics.

options.label: D
options.text: To only be used in video games.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between tensors and mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Tensors are a complex and difficult part of mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: Tensors are a simple and elegant part of mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: Tensors are only used in physics and not in mathematics.

options.label: D
options.text: Tensors are only used in video games and not in mathematics.
